content.raw: Interesting.  We should definitely figure out why the test sometimes fails (there are probably multiple conditions, including [unexpected security group creation errors](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/cloudsim/job/cloudsim-default-devel-precise-amd64/151/testReport/junit/%28root%29/RestTest/test/).  But that doesn't have to happen as part of this pull request.
content.html: Interesting. We should definitely figure out why the test sometimes fails (there are probably multiple conditions, including unexpected security group creation errors. But that doesn't have to happen as part of this pull request.

content.raw: I respectfully disagree: there is no appropriate action here to recover from the absence of cloudsim.zip. The program relies on the existence of the zip file, and the program should throw an exception if the file is not found.
content.html: I respectfully disagree: there is no appropriate action here to recover from the absence of cloudsim.zip. The program relies on the existence of the zip file, and the program should throw an exception if the file is not found.

content.raw:
I don't know why, but the test passed for me.  In case it's relevant, I have this in my `boto.ini`:

~~~
[Boto]
ec2_region_name = us-east-1a
ec2_region_endpoint = ec2.us-east-1.amazonaws.com
~~~
content.html:
I don't know why, but the test passed for me. In case it's relevant, I have this in my boto.ini:

[Boto]
ec2_region_name = us-east-1a
ec2_region_endpoint = ec2.us-east-1.amazonaws.com

content.raw: I was trying to run the rest_integration_test.py and I got an EC2 exception. ``` #!python Traceback (most recent call last): File "tools/rest_integration_test.py", line 320, in test constellation_name=self.papa_cloudsim_name) File "/home/caguero/workspace/cloudsim/cloudsimd/launchers/cloudsim.py", line 595, in create_cloudsim basic_auth_password=password) File "/home/caguero/workspace/cloudsim/cloudsimd/launchers/cloudsim.py", line 345, in launch tags=tags) File "/home/caguero/workspace/cloudsim/cloudsimd/launchers/launch_utils/aws.py", line 93, in acquire_aws_single_server block_device_map=bdm) File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/boto/ec2/connection.py", line 722, in run_instances verb='POST') File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/boto/connection.py", line 1062, in get_object raise self.ResponseError(response.status, response.reason, body) EC2ResponseError: EC2ResponseError: 400 Bad Request AuthFailureNot authorized for images: [ami-91e70ae6]fbfabf11-0347-447e-b49d-247691bb8f56 ``` It seems that the AMI is not public.
content.html:
I was trying to run the rest_integration_test.py and I got an EC2 exception.

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tools/rest_integration_test.py", line 320, in test
    constellation_name=self.papa_cloudsim_name)
  File "/home/caguero/workspace/cloudsim/cloudsimd/launchers/cloudsim.py", line 595, in create_cloudsim
    basic_auth_password=password)
  File "/home/caguero/workspace/cloudsim/cloudsimd/launchers/cloudsim.py", line 345, in launch
    tags=tags)
  File "/home/caguero/workspace/cloudsim/cloudsimd/launchers/launch_utils/aws.py", line 93, in acquire_aws_single_server
    block_device_map=bdm)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/boto/ec2/connection.py", line 722, in run_instances
    verb='POST')
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/boto/connection.py", line 1062, in get_object
    raise self.ResponseError(response.status, response.reason, body)
EC2ResponseError: EC2ResponseError: 400 Bad Request
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<Response><Errors><Error><Code>AuthFailure</Code><Message>Not authorized for images: [ami-91e70ae6]</Message></Error></Errors><RequestID>fbfabf11-0347-447e-b49d-247691bb8f56</RequestID></Response>

It seems that the AMI is not public.

content.raw: The test now includes launching a CloudSim stable from CloudSim, and performing an update of the software. This should prevent any further issues related to the difference between "launching CloudSim from CloudSim" vs "launching CloudSim with create_cloudsim.py"
content.html: The test now includes launching a CloudSim stable from CloudSim, and performing an update of the software. This should prevent any further issues related to the difference between "launching CloudSim from CloudSim" vs "launching CloudSim with create_cloudsim.py"
